text: If I drill down what makes companies fail, it's quite simple. It's just like they don't talk to users, which means they don't find product market fit. And if they don't find product market fit, nothing else really matters. What mistakes do people make is like it is all about that. It's all about talking to customers and learning that you're building something that's actually useful.
speaker: Gustaf Alströmer
context: Lenny asks Gustaf about the most common mistakes that early stage startups make. Gustaf explains that after working with over 600 startups at Y Combinator, he's identified a clear pattern of failure. He emphasizes that finding product market fit is the fundamental requirement for startup success, and this can only be achieved through consistent customer conversations to understand what people actually want and need.
text_ko: 제가 기업들이 실패하는 이유를 파고들어 보면, 사실 굉장히 단순해요. 사용자와 대화하지 않아서 제품-시장 적합성(product-market fit)을 찾지 못하는 거예요. 그걸 찾지 못하면 다른 건 별로 중요하지 않아요. 사람들이 저지르는 실수도 결국 거기에요. 고객과 계속 얘기하면서, 내가 만드는 게 실제로 쓸모 있는지 배우는 게 핵심이에요.
text_zh: 如果我深挖一下公司失败的根本原因，其实很简单。就是他们不跟用户聊天，这就意味着找不到产品市场契合度(product market fit)。如果找不到产品市场契合度(product market fit)，其他什么都白搭。大家犯的错误说白了就是这个。关键就是要跟客户多交流，搞清楚你做的东西到底有没有用。
text_es: Si me pongo a analizar qué es lo que hace que las empresas fracasen, es bastante simple. Es que simplemente no hablan con los usuarios, lo que significa que no logran el ajuste producto-mercado (product market fit). Y si no logran ese ajuste producto-mercado, nada más importa realmente. Los errores que comete la gente van por ahí. Todo se trata de hablar con los clientes y aprender que estás construyendo algo que realmente sirve.

text: The problem is, which anyone who hasn't done sales before that joined YC, they realize this, is that if you take the average customer group in the world, 90% are not early adopters. It doesn't matter if you have something new and cool, they're just not interested. They are not incentivized to take risks in their job to try something new. They're just incentivized to not take risks and just continue what they're doing.
speaker: Gustaf Alströmer
context: Gustaf explains why founders are often afraid to talk to customers and why they get discouraged by rejection. He's describing the reality of customer acquisition - that most potential customers are not early adopters who are willing to try new products. This insight helps founders understand that rejection is normal and expected, not a sign that their product is fundamentally flawed.
text_ko: 문제는, YC(Y Combinator)에 합류하기 전까지 영업(sales)을 해본 적이 없는 사람들은 이걸 금방 깨닫게 된다는 거예요. 전 세계 평균 고객층을 보면 90%가 얼리어답터(early adopters)가 아니에요. 아무리 새롭고 멋진 걸 내놔도 그냥 관심이 없어요. 직장에서 새로운 걸 시도하느라 위험을 감수하도록 유리한 인센티브(incentives)가 주어지지 않고, 오히려 위험을 피하고 하던 대로 계속하려는 인센티브가 더 강하게 작용해요.
text_zh: 问题在于，那些没做过销售就加入YC的人都会意识到这一点：全世界的客户群体里，90%都不是早期采用者(early adopters)。不管你的产品多新多酷，他们就是不感兴趣。他们在工作中没有动力去冒险尝试新东西，反而更有动力不去冒险，就按老路子继续做下去。
text_es: El tema es que, cualquiera que no haya hecho ventas antes y que se haya unido a YC se da cuenta de esto: si tomas al grupo promedio de clientes en el mundo, el 90% no son early adopters. No importa si tienes algo nuevo y genial, simplemente no les interesa. No tienen incentivos en su trabajo para tomar riesgos y probar algo nuevo. Al contrario, tienen incentivos para no tomar riesgos y simplemente seguir haciendo lo que ya hacen.

text: I think the truth is that we're not very good at knowing what's going to succeed. Certainly we cannot figure out who's going to be the really successful company in the batch. That's not possible. What we're good at is knowing what failure looks like. What we sometimes like to tell founders at the beginning of the batch is like, 'If you fail, please do it in some new exciting way. Not one that we've seen 100 times.'
speaker: Gustaf Alströmer
context: Lenny asks Gustaf how good Y Combinator is at predicting which startups will become monster hits like Airbnb or Dropbox. Gustaf gives an honest assessment that even with extensive experience working with over 600 companies, predicting massive success is nearly impossible. Instead, YC focuses on helping founders avoid common failure patterns that they've observed repeatedly across many startups.
text_ko: 사실 우리는 무엇이 성공할지 잘 알지 못해요. 확실히 이번 배치(batch)에서 누가 진짜 크게 성공할 회사가 될지 알아내는 건 불가능해요. 우리가 잘하는 건 실패가 어떤 모습인지 알아보는 거예요. 그래서 배치 초반에 창업자들에게 가끔 이렇게 말해요. "실패한다면 제발 새롭고 흥미로운 방식으로 실패하세요. 우리가 백 번은 본 그런 실패 말고요."
text_zh: 我觉得实话说，我们也不太会预测什么能成功。我们肯定没法看出这一批里哪家公司会真正做大，这根本不可能。但我们擅长的是，一眼就能看出失败是什么样子。所以我们有时候会跟创始人说，"如果你们真要失败的话，至少失败得有点新意，别再用那些我们已经见过一百遍的老套路了。"
text_es: Creo que la realidad es que no somos muy buenos prediciendo qué va a funcionar. Definitivamente no podemos adivinar cuál va a ser la empresa que realmente la va a romper en el grupo. Eso es imposible. En lo que sí somos buenos es en reconocer cómo se ve el fracaso. A veces lo que les decimos a los fundadores al principio es algo así como: "Si van a fracasar, por favor háganlo de alguna manera nueva y emocionante. No de una forma que ya hemos visto cien veces."

text: I think when people think about quality, they often think about, 'What is my personal definition of quality?' I have a bar of quality, but quality to me of a good product idea, a good startup idea, has more to do with the customer think is valuable. And if you move fast by talking to customers and having customer learnings and know the problems, then you will actually come up with something that's high quality.
speaker: Gustaf Alströmer
context: Lenny presents Gustaf with a founder's dilemma about whether to focus on speed versus quality. Gustaf argues that this is a false dichotomy and explains that true quality in startups isn't about the founder's personal standards, but about creating something customers find valuable. He emphasizes that speed in customer discovery actually leads to higher quality products because you understand real problems better.
text_ko: 제 생각엔 사람들이 품질을 생각할 때 보통 '내가 생각하는 품질의 정의는 뭘까?' 같은 개인적인 기준을 떠올려요. 하지만 저는 좋은 제품 아이디어(product idea)나 스타트업 아이디어(startup)는 제 기준보다 고객이 가치 있다고 느끼는지가 더 중요하다고 봐요. 고객과 빠르게 대화하고 고객 인사이트(customer learnings)를 얻어 문제를 정확히 알게 되면 오히려 높은 품질의 결과물이 나오거든요.
text_zh: 我觉得大家一提到质量，往往想的是"我个人对质量的定义是什么？"我有自己的质量标准，但对我来说，一个好产品想法、好的创业点子的质量，更多取决于客户觉得有没有价值。如果你通过跟客户聊天、了解客户需求、摸清楚问题在哪儿来快速行动，那你其实就能做出高质量的东西。
text_es: Creo que cuando la gente piensa en calidad, muchas veces se pregunta: "¿Cuál es mi definición personal de calidad?" Yo tengo mi estándar de calidad, pero para mí, la calidad de una buena idea de producto, de una buena idea de startup, tiene más que ver con lo que el cliente considera valioso. Y si te mueves rápido hablando con clientes, aprendiendo de ellos y conociendo bien los problemas, entonces vas a crear algo que realmente tenga calidad.

text: I don't think that you can just decide... You can't also be fully collaborative, everyone gets decided about everything. So small startups agree on how they decide together. So after that, everyone just follow the process. That's usually how things work out.
speaker: Gustaf Alströmer
context: Gustaf responds to Lenny's question about whether successful founders tend to be more autocratic (like Steve Jobs) or more collaborative in their leadership style. He explains that for small startups, the key isn't being at either extreme, but rather establishing clear decision-making processes that the founding team agrees on and then consistently following those processes to avoid endless rehashing of decisions.
text_ko: 그냥 한 사람이 “결정하면 된다”라고만 할 수는 없다고 생각해요. 반대로 모든 걸 다 같이, 완전 협업으로 모두가 합의해서 결정해야 한다고도 할 수 없고요. 그래서 소규모 스타트업(small startups)들은 누구랑 어떻게 결정을 내릴지 미리 합의해요. 그다음에는 다들 그 프로세스를 따라서 움직이는 경우가 대부분이에요.
text_zh: 我觉得不是说你想怎么决定就怎么决定的...你也不能什么事都让所有人一起商量，每个人对每件事都要参与决策。所以小的创业公司要先商量好大家怎么做决定。定好了之后，大家就按这个流程走。通常都是这么搞的。
text_es: No creo que puedas simplemente decidir... Tampoco puedes ser totalmente colaborativo, que todo el mundo opine sobre cada cosa. Entonces las startups pequeñas se ponen de acuerdo sobre cómo van a tomar decisiones juntos. Y después de eso, todos siguen el proceso. Así es como suelen funcionar las cosas normalmente.

text: In that transition, we're talking about trillions of dollars of money moving from things that cause climate change to things that don't. The scale of this transition is not something we've seen recently. Like software is not that big in comparison. It actually is much smaller than this transition.
speaker: Gustaf Alströmer
context: Gustaf explains why climate tech has become such an attractive area for entrepreneurs and investors. He's describing the massive economic opportunity created by the global transition away from carbon-emitting technologies. This represents a fundamental shift where governments and corporations have committed to changing entire energy systems, creating unprecedented business opportunities that dwarf even the software industry in scale.
text_ko: 그 전환(transition)에서는 기후변화(climate change)를 유발하는 쪽에서 그렇지 않은 쪽으로 수조 달러가 이동한다고 얘기하는 거예요. 이 전환의 규모는 최근에 우리가 본 것과는 비교가 안 되는 수준이에요. 소프트웨어(software) 같은 건 이거에 비하면 규모가 작아요. 사실 훨씬 작죠.
text_zh: 在这个转型过程中，我们说的是万亿美元级别的资金要从那些造成气候变化的领域转向不造成气候变化的领域。这个转型的规模是我们最近都没见过的。就连软件行业跟这个比起来都不算什么，实际上比这个转型要小得多。
text_es: En esa transición, estamos hablando de billones de dólares que se van a mover de cosas que causan el cambio climático a cosas que no lo causan. La magnitud de esta transición es algo que no hemos visto en mucho tiempo. O sea, el software no es tan grande en comparación. En realidad es muchísimo más pequeño que esta transición.
